column2: Kerman-Floyd Elementary School\r14655 West F Street • Kerman
column4: Principal\rgabe.melgoza@kermanusd.com\r\r\r2018-19 School Accountability Report Card\rPublished During the 2019-20 School Year\r\rA Message from the Principal:\rWelcome to Kerman-Floyd Elementary's School Accountability Report Card. As you read this report
column5: \rI believe you will find that what emerges is a picture of a school with a commitment to excellence
column6: \ra faculty that is professionally skilled and personally committed to meeting the learning needs of\rall students
column7: and a student body that as a whole
column8: is well disciplined and motivated. Our school\rcommunity has a great amount of pride and works as a family. The school staff welcomes parent\rand community participation and strives to create a partnership between parents
column10: and\r-------the school. Parents are welcome to visit or work in the classrooms and are highly encouraged to\r-take part in their children's educational process.\rKerman Unified School District\r15218 W. Whitesbridge AvenueWith a large number (57 percent) of English Language Learners (ELL)
column12: CA 93630-1029\rprovide an ELL program that ensures success. We have been able to progress as a school and have\r(559) 843-9000\rshown great progress on the ELPAC (a Language Development Test for English Learners). During\rwww.kermanusd.com\rthe Spring our 3rd - 6th grade students took the  SBAC Standards Based Testing online.\r\rDistrict Governing Board\rDaniel BabshoffMajor Achievements:\rThe focus of the staff this past year was to improve the delivery of instruction to our students and\rMaria Cantuto implement effective
column13: research based curriculum to our students. Many intervention programs\rwere implemented and targeted instruction was given to students. The teachers have attended and\rimplemented curriculum with State Standards and new NGSS Standards with support from the Efrain Guizar\rFresno County Superintendent of Schools with great success.\r\rKindra Melgoza\rFor the past few years staff development was focused on the RTI (Response to Intervention) model\rto meet the needs of our students. The staff was able to better identify needs of students and\rJim Volkoff\rdetermine a plan of action to monitor their progress and make the best use of resources for every\rstudent.\rDistrict Administration\r\rRobert Frausto\rWe will continue to focus on EL students
column14: using the strategies for which the staff received training
column15: \rSuperintendent\rbuilding on ways to help these students who are having difficulty in reading. We will continue to\rMark Ruiz\roffer research based interventions during the school day as well as target instruction in the\rAssistant Superintendent\rclassrooms to meet their needs. We will continue to use the RTI (Response to Intervention ) model\rPersonnel\rto identify students at risk and fit them into an intervention program that will specifically service\r\rtheir deficiencies. We will continue to increase the use of technology in the classrooms to give\rKraig Magnussen\rstudents better access to the skills they need. We have also implemented the PBIS Process (Positive\rAssistant Superintendent\rBehavioral Interventions) and Supports with great success. We have increased our attendance and\rChief Business Official\rdecreased our suspensions and office referrals as a result of the implementation.  We have also\r\rpurchased several mobile computer labs for the classrooms and have a cart in every 1st - 6th grade\rPamela Millspaugh\rclassroom.  We have also added Topcat classroom audio system to the entire school. Every teacher\rAssistant Superintendent of\rhas a SMARTboard
column17: laptop and document camera in their classrooms as well as a teacher\rEducational Services\r\rdesignated iPad. We will also focus on technology for teachers so that they are better able to\ranalyze standardized tests and benchmark tests to determine the needs of each student. We will\ralso focus on science this year with training provided by FCSS PD.
